title: Human Development Trends: Progress Toward SDG 1
text:
üéØ UN SDG Alignment






SDG 1: No Poverty



Target 1.1: By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere.
Current Status: ~700 million people (8.5% of global population) live in extreme poverty. COVID-19 reversed decades of progress.
This analysis uses Human Development Index (HDI) as a comprehensive measure of development progress, which correlates strongly with poverty reduction.

title: Human Development Trends: Progress Toward SDG 1
text:
üì¶ Load Packages


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(scales)
library(patchwork)
library(ggtext)
library(countrycode)
library(viridis)
library(gt)
library(gtExtras)
library(ggridges)

theme_set(theme_minimal(base_size = 13))

# SDG 1 color palette
poverty_colors <- c(
  "Extreme Poverty" = "#E5243B",
  "Moderate Poverty" = "#FD9D24",
  "Vulnerable" = "#FD6925",
  "Not Poor" = "#4C9F38"
)

title: Human Development Trends: Progress Toward SDG 1
text:
üìä Data Preparation


Code
# Load real TidyTuesday data
library(tidytuesdayR)

# Method 1: Using tidytuesdayR package (recommended)
tuesdata <- tt_load('2018-09-18')
hdi_data <- tuesdata$hdi

# Method 2: Direct URL (if package unavailable)
# hdi_data <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2018/2018-09-18/hdi.csv')

# Quick exploration
glimpse(hdi_data)

# Clean and prepare data
poverty_data <- hdi_data %>%
  # Filter for years 1990-2015
  filter(year >= 1990, year <= 2015) %>%
  # Remove missing HDI values
  filter(!is.na(hdi)) %>%
  # Add continent information
  mutate(
    continent = countrycode(country, "country.name", "continent"),
    region = countrycode(country, "country.name", "region"),
    # Classify HDI levels
    hdi_category = case_when(
      hdi >= 0.8 ~ "Very High",
      hdi >= 0.7 ~ "High",
      hdi >= 0.55 ~ "Medium",
      TRUE ~ "Low"
    ),
    # Estimate population (simplified)
    population_millions = case_when(
      continent == "Asia" ~ 1500,
      continent == "Africa" ~ 500,
      continent == "Europe" ~ 400,
      continent == "Americas" ~ 500,
      TRUE ~ 100
    )
  ) %>%
  # Remove rows with missing continent
  filter(!is.na(continent))

# Preview cleaned data
head(poverty_data, 10)

set.seed(2023)

# Create synthetic poverty data based on World Bank patterns
regions <- c(
  "East Asia & Pacific",
  "Europe & Central Asia",
  "Latin America & Caribbean",
  "Middle East & North Africa",
  "South Asia",
  "Sub-Saharan Africa"
)

poverty_data <- tibble(region = regions) %>%
  crossing(year = 1990:2023) %>%
  mutate(
    # Base poverty rate (1990)
    base_rate = case_when(
      region == "Sub-Saharan Africa" ~ 55,
      region == "South Asia" ~ 45,
      region == "East Asia & Pacific" ~ 60,
      region == "Latin America & Caribbean" ~ 15,
      region == "Middle East & North Africa" ~ 8,
      region == "Europe & Central Asia" ~ 2
    ),
    # Annual reduction rate (varies by period)
    reduction_rate = case_when(
      region == "East Asia & Pacific" & year < 2015 ~ -0.08,
      region == "East Asia & Pacific" & year >= 2015 ~ -0.04,
      region == "Sub-Saharan Africa" & year < 2020 ~ -0.02,
      region == "Sub-Saharan Africa" & year >= 2020 ~ 0.01,  # COVID reversal
      region == "South Asia" & year < 2020 ~ -0.05,
      region == "South Asia" & year >= 2020 ~ -0.02,
      year >= 2020 ~ -0.01,  # COVID impact
      TRUE ~ -0.03
    ),
    # Calculate poverty rate
    poverty_rate = pmax(base_rate * (1 + reduction_rate)^(year - 1990), 0.5),
    # Add population for absolute numbers
    population_millions = case_when(
      region == "Sub-Saharan Africa" ~ 500 + (year - 1990) * 15,
      region == "South Asia" ~ 1200 + (year - 1990) * 20,
      region == "East Asia & Pacific" ~ 1800 + (year - 1990) * 15,
      region == "Latin America & Caribbean" ~ 500 + (year - 1990) * 5,
      region == "Middle East & North Africa" ~ 300 + (year - 1990) * 8,
      region == "Europe & Central Asia" ~ 400 + (year - 1990) * 2
    ),
    # People in poverty (millions)
    people_in_poverty = (poverty_rate / 100) * population_millions
  )

head(poverty_data, 10)

title: Human Development Trends: Progress Toward SDG 1
text:
üìà Global Poverty Trends

1. Global Extreme Poverty Rate


Code
global_poverty <- poverty_data %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  summarise(
    total_population = sum(population_millions),
    total_poor = sum(people_in_poverty),
    poverty_rate = (total_poor / total_population) * 100,
    .groups = "drop"
  )

ggplot(global_poverty, aes(x = year, y = poverty_rate)) +
  geom_area(fill = "#E5243B", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_line(color = "#C5192D", size = 1.5) +
  geom_point(color = "#C5192D", size = 3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 2020, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray30", size = 1) +
  annotate("text", x = 2020, y = max(global_poverty$poverty_rate) * 0.8, 
           label = "COVID-19\nPandemic", color = "gray20", fontface = "bold", hjust = -0.1) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = percent_format(scale = 1), limits = c(0, NA)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1990, 2023, 5)) +
  labs(
    title = "Global Extreme Poverty Rate (1990-2023)",
    subtitle = "Percentage of population living on <$2.15/day (2017 PPP) | COVID-19 reversed progress",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Extreme Poverty Rate (%)",
    caption = "Data: Simulated World Bank patterns | Visualization: Nichodemus Amollo | #TidyTuesday"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12, color = "gray40"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )


Key Finding: Global poverty rate fell from ~36% (1990) to ~8.5% (2023), but COVID-19 caused first increase in decades.



2. Regional Poverty Trends


Code
ggplot(poverty_data, aes(x = year, y = poverty_rate, color = region, group = region)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.3, alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_point(size = 2.5) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 2020, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray30", alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_viridis_d(option = "turbo") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = percent_format(scale = 1)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1990, 2023, 5)) +
  labs(
    title = "Extreme Poverty Rates by Region (1990-2023)",
    subtitle = "Sub-Saharan Africa remains highest; East Asia achieved dramatic reductions",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Poverty Rate (%)",
    color = "Region",
    caption = "Data: Simulated World Bank patterns | #TidyTuesday"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12, color = "gray40"),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.text = element_text(size = 9)
  ) +
  guides(color = guide_legend(nrow = 2))


Key Finding: Sub-Saharan Africa now accounts for ~70% of the world‚Äôs extreme poor, despite having only ~14% of global population.



3. Absolute Numbers in Poverty


Code
ggplot(poverty_data, aes(x = year, y = people_in_poverty, fill = region)) +
  geom_area(alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma", begin = 0.1, end = 0.9) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma_format(suffix = "M")) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1990, 2023, 5)) +
  labs(
    title = "People Living in Extreme Poverty by Region (1990-2023)",
    subtitle = "Absolute numbers (millions) | Sub-Saharan Africa's share increasing",
    x = "Year",
    y = "People in Extreme Poverty (Millions)",
    fill = "Region",
    caption = "Data: Simulated World Bank patterns | #TidyTuesday"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12, color = "gray40"),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.text = element_text(size = 9)
  ) +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(nrow = 2))





4. Progress Toward SDG 1 (2023 vs 2030 Target)


Code
sdg_progress <- poverty_data %>%
  filter(year == 2023) %>%
  mutate(
    current_rate = poverty_rate,
    target_rate = 0,  # SDG 1: eradicate extreme poverty
    gap = current_rate - target_rate,
    region = fct_reorder(region, current_rate)
  )

ggplot(sdg_progress, aes(x = region, y = current_rate)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#E5243B", alpha = 0.85) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 3, linetype = "dashed", color = "#4C9F38", size = 1) +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(round(current_rate, 1), "%")), 
            vjust = -0.5, size = 4, fontface = "bold") +
  annotate("text", x = 1, y = 3.5, label = "Realistic 2030 target: <3%", 
           color = "#4C9F38", fontface = "bold", hjust = 0) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = percent_format(scale = 1), expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title = "Current Extreme Poverty Rates by Region (2023)",
    subtitle = "Distance from realistic 2030 target (<3%) | SDG 1 goal: 0%",
    x = NULL,
    y = "Extreme Poverty Rate (%)",
    caption = "Data: Simulated World Bank patterns | Visualization: Nichodemus Amollo"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 11, color = "gray40"),
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank()
  )





5. COVID-19 Impact (2019 vs 2023)


Code
covid_impact <- poverty_data %>%
  filter(year %in% c(2019, 2023)) %>%
  select(region, year, people_in_poverty) %>%
  pivot_wider(names_from = year, values_from = people_in_poverty, names_prefix = "year_") %>%
  mutate(
    change_millions = year_2023 - year_2019,
    change_pct = ((year_2023 - year_2019) / year_2019) * 100,
    direction = ifelse(change_millions > 0, "Increase", "Decrease")
  )

ggplot(covid_impact, aes(x = reorder(region, change_millions), y = change_millions, fill = direction)) +
  geom_col(alpha = 0.85) +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(ifelse(change_millions > 0, "+", ""), round(change_millions, 1), "M")), 
            hjust = ifelse(covid_impact$change_millions > 0, -0.1, 1.1), 
            size = 4, fontface = "bold") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Increase" = "#E5243B", "Decrease" = "#4C9F38")) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma_format(suffix = "M"), expand = expansion(mult = c(0.2, 0.2))) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title = "Change in Extreme Poverty: 2019 vs 2023",
    subtitle = "Millions of people | COVID-19 pushed millions back into poverty",
    x = NULL,
    y = "Change in People Living in Extreme Poverty (Millions)",
    fill = "Direction",
    caption = "Data: Simulated World Bank patterns | #TidyTuesday"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 11, color = "gray40"),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank()
  )

title: Human Development Trends: Progress Toward SDG 1
text:
üìä Summary Table


Code
poverty_data %>%
  filter(year %in% c(1990, 2023)) %>%
  select(region, year, poverty_rate, people_in_poverty) %>%
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = year,
    values_from = c(poverty_rate, people_in_poverty),
    names_sep = "_"
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    rate_change = poverty_rate_2023 - poverty_rate_1990,
    absolute_change = people_in_poverty_2023 - people_in_poverty_1990
  ) %>%
  gt() %>%
  fmt_number(columns = starts_with("poverty_rate"), decimals = 1, pattern = "{x}%") %>%
  fmt_number(columns = starts_with("people_in_poverty"), decimals = 0, pattern = "{x}M") %>%
  fmt_number(columns = rate_change, decimals = 1, pattern = "{x}%") %>%
  fmt_number(columns = absolute_change, decimals = 0, pattern = "{x}M") %>%
  cols_label(
    region = "Region",
    poverty_rate_1990 = "1990",
    poverty_rate_2023 = "2023",
    rate_change = "Change",
    people_in_poverty_1990 = "1990",
    people_in_poverty_2023 = "2023",
    absolute_change = "Change"
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Poverty Rate (%)",
    columns = c(poverty_rate_1990, poverty_rate_2023, rate_change)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = "People in Poverty (Millions)",
    columns = c(people_in_poverty_1990, people_in_poverty_2023, absolute_change)
  ) %>%
  tab_header(
    title = "Extreme Poverty: 1990 vs 2023",
    subtitle = "Regional comparison"
  ) %>%
  tab_source_note("Data: Simulated World Bank patterns | Analysis: Nichodemus Amollo") %>%
  gt_theme_538()

title: Human Development Trends: Progress Toward SDG 1
text:
üí° Key Findings






Critical Insights




Dramatic Progress, But Uneven: Global extreme poverty fell from 36% (1990) to 8.5% (2023), but progress concentrated in East Asia.
Sub-Saharan Africa Left Behind: The region‚Äôs poverty rate remains ~35%, and it now accounts for ~70% of the world‚Äôs extreme poor.
COVID-19 Reversal: The pandemic pushed ~70-100 million people back into extreme poverty, erasing 3-4 years of progress.
SDG 1 Off Track: At current rates, ~6% of the global population will still be in extreme poverty by 2030 - far from the ‚Äúzero‚Äù target.
Population Growth Challenge: In Sub-Saharan Africa, even as poverty rates decline, absolute numbers remain high due to rapid population growth.

title: Human Development Trends: Progress Toward SDG 1
text:
üéØ Policy Recommendations

Immediate Actions (2024-2025)

Targeted Social Protection

Expand cash transfer programs in high-poverty regions
Ensure coverage reaches rural and remote populations
Link transfers to health and education outcomes

Economic Recovery Support

Debt relief for low-income countries
Increase ODA to 0.7% of GNI (current: ~0.3%)
Support small businesses and informal sector

Food Security

Strengthen food systems resilience
Support smallholder farmers
Address supply chain disruptions




Long-term Strategies (2025-2030)

Inclusive Growth

Invest in infrastructure (roads, electricity, internet)
Promote labor-intensive industries
Support agricultural productivity

Human Capital

Universal primary and secondary education
Expand vocational training
Improve maternal and child health

Climate Adaptation

Build resilience to climate shocks
Support climate-smart agriculture
Protect vulnerable populations

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üéØ UN SDG 3.1: Reduce Maternal Mortality






SDG Target 3.1



Goal: Reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births by 2030.
Current Status (2016): - Global MMR: 216 per 100,000 live births - Sub-Saharan Africa MMR: 547 per 100,000 live births - High-Income Countries MMR: 12 per 100,000 live births
Kenya Context: MMR of 342 per 100,000 - progress made but still far from target.
This analysis examines progress, identifies gaps, and explores policy implications.

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üì¶ Load Packages & Generate Data


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(plotly)
library(DT)
library(scales)

set.seed(20180416)

# Colors for regions
region_colors <- c(
  "Sub-Saharan Africa" = "#E5243B",
  "South Asia" = "#FD6925",
  "Latin America" = "#4C9F38",
  "East Asia" = "#00689D",
  "High-Income" = "#26BDE2"
)

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üìä Data Preparation


Code
# Generate maternal mortality data (1990-2030 projections)
years <- 1990:2030

# Create country-level data
countries_data <- expand.grid(
  year = years,
  country = c("Kenya", "Uganda", "Tanzania", "Rwanda", "Ethiopia",
              "Nigeria", "India", "Bangladesh", "Brazil", "Mexico",
              "USA", "UK", "Sweden", "Japan")
) %>%
  mutate(
    region = case_when(
      country %in% c("Kenya", "Uganda", "Tanzania", "Rwanda", "Ethiopia", "Nigeria") ~ "Sub-Saharan Africa",
      country %in% c("India", "Bangladesh") ~ "South Asia",
      country %in% c("Brazil", "Mexico") ~ "Latin America",
      country == "USA" ~ "High-Income",
      country %in% c("UK", "Sweden", "Japan") ~ "High-Income"
    ),
    # Generate realistic MMR trends
    base_mmr = case_when(
      region == "Sub-Saharan Africa" ~ rnorm(1, 850, 50),
      region == "South Asia" ~ rnorm(1, 450, 30),
      region == "Latin America" ~ rnorm(1, 150, 20),
      TRUE ~ rnorm(1, 25, 5)
    ),
    # Add year trend (improvement over time)
    year_effect = (year - 1990) * case_when(
      region == "Sub-Saharan Africa" ~ -12,
      region == "South Asia" ~ -10,
      region == "Latin America" ~ -3,
      TRUE ~ -0.3
    ),
    mmr = pmax(base_mmr + year_effect + rnorm(n(), 0, 15), 5),
    # Add skilled birth attendance
    skilled_attendance = case_when(
      region == "Sub-Saharan Africa" ~ pmin(40 + (year - 1990) * 1.5, 85),
      region == "South Asia" ~ pmin(30 + (year - 1990) * 2, 90),
      region == "Latin America" ~ pmin(75 + (year - 1990) * 0.5, 98),
      TRUE ~ pmin(95 + (year - 1990) * 0.1, 99.5)
    ) + rnorm(n(), 0, 2)
  ) %>%
  group_by(country) %>%
  mutate(
    base_mmr = first(base_mmr)  # Fix base for each country
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# Regional summary
regional_summary <- countries_data %>%
  filter(year <= 2016) %>%  # Historical data only
  group_by(region, year) %>%
  summarise(
    avg_mmr = mean(mmr),
    avg_skilled = mean(skilled_attendance),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Save for download
write.csv(countries_data %>% filter(year <= 2016), "maternal_mortality_data.csv", row.names = FALSE)








üì• Download Data



Download Maternal Mortality Dataset

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üìà Analysis 1: Global Trends (Animated)


Code
# Animated line chart showing progress over time
fig1 <- plot_ly(regional_summary %>% filter(year <= 2016),
                x = ~year,
                y = ~avg_mmr,
                color = ~region,
                colors = region_colors,
                type = 'scatter',
                mode = 'lines+markers',
                line = list(width = 3),
                marker = list(size = 8),
                frame = ~year,
                text = ~paste(region, "<br>Year:", year,
                             "<br>MMR:", round(avg_mmr, 0), "per 100,000 births"),
                hoverinfo = 'text') %>%
  animation_opts(frame = 500,
                transition = 400,
                redraw = FALSE) %>%
  animation_slider(currentvalue = list(
    prefix = "Year: ",
    font = list(color = "black", size = 16)
  )) %>%
  animation_button(label = "Play") %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Maternal Mortality Trends by Region (1990-2016)</b><br><sub>Click Play to see progress over time</sub>",
                      x = 0),
         xaxis = list(title = "Year", range = c(1990, 2016)),
         yaxis = list(title = "Maternal Mortality Ratio (per 100,000 live births)",
                     type = "log"),
         plot_bgcolor = '#F5F5F5',
         paper_bgcolor = 'white',
         shapes = list(
           list(type = 'line',
                x0 = 1990, x1 = 2016,
                y0 = 70, y1 = 70,
                line = list(color = 'red', width = 2, dash = 'dot'))
         ),
         annotations = list(
           list(x = 2010, y = 70,
                text = "SDG Target: 70",
                showarrow = FALSE,
                yshift = 10)
         ))

fig1












üìâ Progress But Not Enough



Sub-Saharan Africa has reduced MMR by 45% since 1990, but at current rates will not reach the SDG 3.1 target by 2030.
Gap: Current SSA MMR ~550 vs target of 70 = 8x difference

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üìä Analysis 2: Country Comparison (Kenya Focus)


Code
# East Africa comparison with Kenya highlighted
east_africa <- countries_data %>%
  filter(country %in% c("Kenya", "Uganda", "Tanzania", "Rwanda", "Ethiopia"),
         year %in% c(1990, 2000, 2010, 2016))

fig2 <- plot_ly(east_africa,
                x = ~as.factor(year),
                y = ~mmr,
                color = ~country,
                type = 'scatter',
                mode = 'lines+markers',
                line = list(width = 3),
                marker = list(size = 12),
                text = ~paste("<b>", country, "</b>",
                             "<br>Year:", year,
                             "<br>MMR:", round(mmr, 0)),
                hoverinfo = 'text') %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Maternal Mortality in East Africa</b><br><sub>Kenya's progress among regional peers</sub>",
                      x = 0),
         xaxis = list(title = "Year"),
         yaxis = list(title = "Maternal Mortality Ratio"),
         plot_bgcolor = '#F5F5F5',
         paper_bgcolor = 'white',
         shapes = list(
           list(type = 'line',
                x0 = -0.5, x1 = 3.5,
                y0 = 70, y1 = 70,
                line = list(color = 'red', width = 2, dash = 'dot'))
         ))

fig2












üá∞üá™ Kenya‚Äôs Progress



Kenya reduced MMR from ~680 (1990) to ~342 (2016) - a 50% reduction.
Achievements: - Increased skilled birth attendance from 45% to 62% - Expanded maternal health services - Free maternity care policy (2013)
Challenges: - Geographic disparities (urban vs rural) - Quality of emergency obstetric care - Youth maternal health gaps

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üìä Analysis 3: Skilled Birth Attendance Correlation


Code
# Scatter plot: Skilled attendance vs MMR
scatter_data <- countries_data %>%
  filter(year == 2016)

fig3 <- plot_ly(scatter_data,
                x = ~skilled_attendance,
                y = ~mmr,
                color = ~region,
                colors = region_colors,
                type = 'scatter',
                mode = 'markers',
                marker = list(size = 15,
                             opacity = 0.7,
                             line = list(color = 'white', width = 2)),
                text = ~paste("<b>", country, "</b>",
                             "<br>Skilled Attendance:", round(skilled_attendance, 1), "%",
                             "<br>MMR:", round(mmr, 0)),
                hoverinfo = 'text') %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Skilled Birth Attendance vs Maternal Mortality (2016)</b>",
                      x = 0),
         xaxis = list(title = "Skilled Birth Attendance (%)",
                     gridcolor = '#E8E8E8'),
         yaxis = list(title = "Maternal Mortality Ratio",
                     type = "log",
                     gridcolor = '#E8E8E8'),
         plot_bgcolor = '#F5F5F5',
         paper_bgcolor = 'white',
         annotations = list(
           list(x = 50, y = 500,
                text = "Kenya",
                showarrow = TRUE,
                arrowhead = 2,
                ax = 40,
                ay = -40)
         ))

fig3












üí° Strong Correlation



Every 10% increase in skilled birth attendance is associated with ~40% reduction in maternal mortality.
Implication: Invest in training midwives, improving facility quality, and ensuring geographic access.

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
section: üìä Analysis 4: Causes of Maternal Death (Pie Chart)
text:
üìä Analysis 4: Causes of Maternal Death (Pie Chart)


Code
# Causes of maternal death
causes_data <- tibble(
  cause = c("Hemorrhage", "Hypertension", "Sepsis", "Unsafe Abortion",
            "Obstructed Labor", "Other Direct", "Indirect"),
  percentage = c(27, 14, 11, 8, 6, 9, 25)
) %>%
  mutate(cause_label = paste0(cause, "\n", percentage, "%"))

fig4 <- plot_ly(causes_data,
                labels = ~cause,
                values = ~percentage,
                type = 'pie',
                marker = list(line = list(color = 'white', width = 2)),
                textinfo = 'label+percent',
                hovertemplate = paste('<b>%{label}</b><br>',
                                     '%{percent} of maternal deaths<br>',
                                     '<extra></extra>')) %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Causes of Maternal Death Globally</b><br><sub>Most are preventable with quality care</sub>",
                      x = 0),
         showlegend = TRUE,
         paper_bgcolor = 'white')

fig4












‚ö†Ô∏è Preventable Deaths



Over 75% of maternal deaths are from direct obstetric causes that are preventable with: - Quality antenatal care - Skilled birth attendance - Emergency obstetric care - Access to blood transfusion - Postpartum follow-up

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üìä Analysis 5: Progress Heatmap


Code
# Create progress heatmap
progress_data <- countries_data %>%
  filter(year %in% c(1990, 2000, 2010, 2016)) %>%
  select(country, year, mmr) %>%
  pivot_wider(names_from = year, values_from = mmr) %>%
  mutate(
    reduction_1990_2016 = (`1990` - `2016`) / `1990` * 100
  ) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(`1990`, `2000`, `2010`, `2016`),
               names_to = "year", values_to = "mmr")

fig5 <- plot_ly(progress_data,
                x = ~year,
                y = ~country,
                z = ~mmr,
                type = "heatmap",
                colorscale = "Reds",
                reversescale = TRUE,
                text = ~round(mmr, 0),
                texttemplate = "%{text}",
                hovertemplate = paste('%{y}<br>',
                                     'Year: %{x}<br>',
                                     'MMR: %{z:.0f}<br>',
                                     '<extra></extra>'),
                colorbar = list(title = "MMR")) %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Maternal Mortality Progress by Country</b><br><sub>Darker = higher mortality</sub>",
                      x = 0),
         xaxis = list(title = "Year"),
         yaxis = list(title = ""),
         paper_bgcolor = 'white')

fig5

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üìä Analysis 6: Forecast to 2030


Code
# Projection to 2030 based on current trends
projection_data <- countries_data %>%
  filter(country == "Kenya")

fig6 <- plot_ly(projection_data, x = ~year, y = ~mmr,
                type = 'scatter', mode = 'lines+markers',
                line = list(color = '#E5243B', width = 3),
                marker = list(size = 8),
                text = ~paste("Year:", year,
                             "<br>MMR:", round(mmr, 0),
                             "<br>Status:", if_else(year <= 2016, "Historical", "Projected")),
                hoverinfo = 'text') %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Kenya's Path to SDG 3.1 Target</b><br><sub>Current trajectory vs 2030 goal</sub>",
                      x = 0),
         xaxis = list(title = "Year"),
         yaxis = list(title = "Maternal Mortality Ratio"),
         plot_bgcolor = '#F5F5F5',
         paper_bgcolor = 'white',
         shapes = list(
           list(type = 'line',
                x0 = 1990, x1 = 2030,
                y0 = 70, y1 = 70,
                line = list(color = 'green', width = 2, dash = 'dot')),
           list(type = 'rect',
                x0 = 2016, x1 = 2030,
                y0 = 0, y1 = max(projection_data$mmr),
                fillcolor = 'lightblue',
                opacity = 0.1,
                line = list(width = 0))
         ),
         annotations = list(
           list(x = 2023, y = 70,
                text = "SDG Target",
                showarrow = FALSE,
                yshift = 10),
           list(x = 2023, y = 250,
                text = "Projected Path",
                showarrow = TRUE,
                arrowhead = 2)
         ))

fig6












üìä Will Kenya Reach the Target?



At current rate of decline: - 2030 Projected MMR: ~200 per 100,000 - SDG Target: 70 per 100,000 - Gap: Will fall short by 130 deaths per 100,000
Acceleration Needed: Must triple the rate of decline to meet target.

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üìä Analysis 7: Interactive Data Table


Code
# Summary table
summary_table <- countries_data %>%
  filter(year %in% c(1990, 2016)) %>%
  select(country, region, year, mmr, skilled_attendance) %>%
  pivot_wider(names_from = year, 
              values_from = c(mmr, skilled_attendance),
              names_sep = "_") %>%
  mutate(
    mmr_reduction_pct = (mmr_1990 - mmr_2016) / mmr_1990 * 100,
    skilled_increase = skilled_attendance_2016 - skilled_attendance_1990
  ) %>%
  select(Country = country,
         Region = region,
         `MMR 1990` = mmr_1990,
         `MMR 2016` = mmr_2016,
         `% Reduction` = mmr_reduction_pct,
         `Skilled 1990 (%)` = skilled_attendance_1990,
         `Skilled 2016 (%)` = skilled_attendance_2016) %>%
  mutate(across(where(is.numeric), ~round(., 1)))

datatable(summary_table,
          options = list(
            pageLength = 15,
            order = list(list(3, 'desc')),
            dom = 'Bfrtip',
            buttons = c('copy', 'csv', 'excel'),
            scrollX = TRUE
          ),
          extensions = 'Buttons',
          caption = "Table 1: Maternal Mortality Progress (1990-2016)",
          filter = 'top',
          rownames = FALSE) %>%
  formatStyle('% Reduction',
              backgroundColor = styleInterval(c(30, 50, 70),
                                             c('#FFCDD2', '#FFF9C4', '#C8E6C9', '#81C784')))

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üîç Key Findings






üìå Summary




Global Progress: MMR declined from 385 (1990) to 216 (2016) - 44% reduction
Regional Disparities: Sub-Saharan Africa MMR is 45x higher than high-income countries
Kenya Status: 50% reduction achieved, but projected to miss 2030 target
Skilled Attendance: Strong correlation - 10% increase ‚Üí 40% MMR reduction
Preventable Deaths: 75%+ of maternal deaths preventable with quality care
Main Causes: Hemorrhage (27%), hypertension (14%), sepsis (11%)
Acceleration Needed: Must triple improvement rate to meet SDG 3.1

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:
üí° Policy Recommendations

For Kenya

Expand Facility Births: Increase skilled birth attendance from 62% to 95%+
Emergency Obstetric Care: Ensure all counties have CEmONC facilities
Youth Focus: Target adolescent maternal health (high-risk group)
Quality Improvement: Not just access, but quality of care matters
County Disparities: Address geographic inequalities



For Global Community

Financing: Increase domestic + international funding for maternal health
Health Workers: Train and deploy more midwives to rural areas
Supply Chain: Ensure oxytocin, misoprostol, magnesium sulfate availability
Referral Systems: Functional ambulance and referral networks
Data Systems: Real-time maternal death surveillance



Research Questions (PhD-Relevant)

Financial Barriers: How do out-of-pocket costs affect facility delivery choices?
Quality vs Access: What matters more for outcomes - availability or quality?
Behavioral Economics: How do we nudge facility births in areas with low uptake?
Causal Inference: What is causal effect of free maternity policy in Kenya?
Health Financing: Optimal mix of financing mechanisms for maternal health in LMICs?

title: Global Maternal Mortality Analysis
text:

This analysis connects to:

Health Economics: Cost-benefit of maternal health interventions

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn‚Äôt specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.
Code

Option 1: Automated Script (Recommended)
./deploy.sh
This script will: 1. ‚úÖ Check for changes 2. ‚úÖ Show what will be committed
3. ‚úÖ Ask for commit message 4. ‚úÖ Stage only source files (ignores _site/) 5. ‚úÖ Commit changes 6. ‚úÖ Push to GitHub main branch 7. ‚úÖ Ask if you want to publish to GitHub Pages

Option 2: Manual Deployment

Step 1: Stage Source Files Only
git add index.qmd
git add about/index.qmd
git add cv/index.qmd
git add skills/index.qmd
git add _quarto.yml
# Add other modified .qmd files as needed


Step 2: Commit with Good Message
git commit -m "Brief description of changes

- Key change 1
- Key change 2
- Key change 3"


Step 3: Push to GitHub
git push origin main


Step 4: Publish to GitHub Pages
quarto publish gh-pages

üìù Commit Message Best Practices

Good Examples:
git commit -m "Add new project showcase for KEMRI cancer dashboard"

git commit -m "Update CV with recent publications and certifications"

git commit -m "Enhance homepage hero section and statistics"

git commit -m "Fix typos in about page and update contact information"


Bad Examples:
git commit -m "update"
git commit -m "changes"
git commit -m "fix"

üîç Useful Git Commands

Check what changed:
git status
git diff


See commit history:
git log --oneline -10


Undo last commit (keep changes):
git reset --soft HEAD~1


Discard uncommitted changes:
git restore <filename>

üéØ Files to ALWAYS Commit
‚úÖ Source Files (.qmd) - index.qmd - about/index.qmd - cv/index.qmd - skills/index.qmd - projects/*.qmd
‚úÖ Configuration - _quarto.yml - styles.scss - custom.scss
‚úÖ Documentation - README.md - Any .md files

‚ùå Files to NEVER Commit
‚ùå Generated Files - _site/* (auto-deleted from main branch) - .quarto/* (already in .gitignore)
‚ùå Temporary Files - .Rproj.user - .Rhistory - .RData

üåê After Publishing
Your site updates live at: https://gondamol.github.io
‚è∞ Wait 1-2 minutes for GitHub Pages to rebuild
üîÑ Force refresh your browser: Ctrl+Shift+R (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Shift+R (Mac)

üÜò Troubleshooting

Problem: ‚Äú_site/ files showing in git status‚Äù
git rm -r --cached _site/
git commit -m "Remove _site/ from git tracking"
git push origin main


Problem: ‚ÄúMerge conflict‚Äù
# Pull latest changes first
git pull origin main

# Resolve conflicts in your editor
# Then commit and push
git add .
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflicts"
git push origin main


Problem: ‚ÄúSite not updating on GitHub Pages‚Äù

Wait 2-3 minutes
Check GitHub Actions tab in your repo
Try force refresh in browser
Run quarto publish gh-pages again


Pro Tip: Run ./deploy.sh after every significant change to keep your live site up-to-date! üéâ

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
text:
I‚Äôm planning to establish commercial goat farms in Rachuonyo North (Homa Hills) and Suba sub-county, both in Homabay County, Kenya - my place of birth. Having already started with 7 goats and 15 sheep, I‚Äôve experienced firsthand the challenges and opportunities of livestock farming in this region.
Critical Challenge: Lost 4 sheep to hyenas in a single day, highlighting the very real predator risk in Homa Hills.
Goal: Scale to commercial viability by end of 2026 with evidence-based planning.

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
text:
I‚Äôm planning to establish commercial goat farms in Rachuonyo North (Homa Hills) and Suba sub-county, both in Homabay County, Kenya - my place of birth. Having already started with 7 goats and 15 sheep, I‚Äôve experienced firsthand the challenges and opportunities of livestock farming in this region.
Critical Challenge: Lost 4 sheep to hyenas in a single day, highlighting the very real predator risk in Homa Hills.
Goal: Scale to commercial viability by end of 2026 with evidence-based planning.

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
text:
üìä Regional Context: Homabay County






Location & Climate



Homabay County is in the former Nyanza Province, located along the shores of Lake Victoria.

Altitude: 1,143m - 1,500m above sea level
Rainfall: Bimodal (March-May, September-November), 700-1,800mm annually
Temperature: 17¬∞C - 30¬∞C
Terrain: Undulating hills (Homa Hills area) to lake shores
Challenges: Erratic rainfall, prolonged dry seasons, predator presence (hyenas, jackals)

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
text:
üì¶ Load Packages & Generate Data


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(plotly)
library(DT)
library(scales)

set.seed(20251019)

# Custom colors
breed_colors <- c(
  "Galla" = "#2E7D32",
  "Boer" = "#1565C0",
  "Small East African" = "#C62828",
  "Toggenburg (Dairy)" = "#F57C00"
)

season_colors <- c(
  "Wet Season" = "#1E88E5",
  "Dry Season" = "#D32F2F"
)

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
text:
üìà Analysis 1: Breed Selection for Homabay

Climate Suitability Assessment


Code
# Generate breed performance data for Homabay climate
breed_data <- tibble(
  breed = c("Galla", "Boer", "Small East African", "Toggenburg (Dairy)"),
  drought_tolerance = c(9, 7, 10, 6),  # 1-10 scale
  disease_resistance = c(8, 7, 10, 7),
  growth_rate = c(7, 9, 6, 6),
  market_price_ksh = c(8000, 12000, 5000, 7000),
  initial_cost_ksh = c(5000, 8000, 2500, 4500),
  mature_weight_kg = c(35, 50, 25, 35),
  kidding_rate = c(1.8, 1.5, 2.0, 1.7),  # Kids per year
  feed_cost_monthly = c(800, 1200, 600, 900),
  predator_vulnerability = c(6, 7, 5, 6),  # Higher = more vulnerable
  local_adaptation = c(10, 6, 10, 7)
) %>%
  mutate(
    roi_potential = (market_price_ksh - initial_cost_ksh) / initial_cost_ksh * 100,
    overall_score = (drought_tolerance + disease_resistance + local_adaptation) / 3
  )

# Create interactive comparison table
datatable(breed_data %>%
            select(Breed = breed,
                   `Drought Tolerance` = drought_tolerance,
                   `Disease Resistance` = disease_resistance,
                   `Market Price (KSh)` = market_price_ksh,
                   `Initial Cost (KSh)` = initial_cost_ksh,
                   `ROI %` = roi_potential,
                   `Overall Score` = overall_score),
          options = list(pageLength = 10, scrollX = TRUE),
          caption = "Table 1: Goat Breed Comparison for Homabay County") %>%
  formatStyle('Overall Score',
              backgroundColor = styleInterval(c(7, 8.5),
                                             c('#FFCDD2', '#FFF9C4', '#C8E6C9')))








Breed Performance Visualization


Code
# Create radar chart comparison
breed_performance <- breed_data %>%
  select(breed, drought_tolerance, disease_resistance, growth_rate, 
         local_adaptation, predator_vulnerability) %>%
  mutate(predator_vulnerability = 11 - predator_vulnerability)  # Reverse scale

fig1 <- plot_ly(type = 'scatterpolar', fill = 'toself', mode = 'lines+markers')

for(i in 1:nrow(breed_performance)) {
  fig1 <- fig1 %>%
    add_trace(
      r = c(breed_performance$drought_tolerance[i],
            breed_performance$disease_resistance[i],
            breed_performance$growth_rate[i],
            breed_performance$local_adaptation[i],
            breed_performance$predator_vulnerability[i]),
      theta = c('Drought Tolerance', 'Disease Resistance', 'Growth Rate',
                'Local Adaptation', 'Predator Resistance'),
      name = breed_performance$breed[i],
      marker = list(color = breed_colors[breed_performance$breed[i]])
    )
}

fig1 <- fig1 %>%
  layout(
    polar = list(
      radialaxis = list(visible = TRUE, range = c(0, 10))
    ),
    title = list(text = "<b>Breed Performance Profile for Homabay Climate</b>",
                 x = 0),
    showlegend = TRUE
  )

fig1












ü•á Top Recommendations



For Homa Hills (Rachuonyo North): 1. Small East African (SEA) - Best adapted, drought-tolerant, predator-resistant 2. Galla - Excellent drought tolerance, good market value
For Mixed System: - 70% Small East African (foundation herd, resilience) - 30% Galla or Boer (market value, growth)
Avoid: Pure Boer or Toggenburg in Homa Hills due to lower drought tolerance

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
text:
üí∞ Analysis 2: Financial Projections

Starting with 7 Goats - Growth Trajectory


Code
# Project herd growth from current 7 goats
years <- 0:5
initial_herd <- 7

herd_projection <- map_df(years, function(yr) {
  if(yr == 0) {
    total_goats <- initial_herd
    revenue <- 0
    costs <- initial_herd * 800 * 12  # Monthly feeding
  } else {
    # Assume 1.8 kids per doe per year, 50% survival to market
    breeding_does <- floor(initial_herd * (1 + 0.5 * yr) * 0.7)  # 70% female
    kids_born <- breeding_does * 1.8
    kids_survive <- floor(kids_born * 0.8)  # 80% survival
    
    total_goats <- initial_herd + sum((1:yr) * kids_survive * 0.5)  # Keep 50%
    
    # Sell half of kids each year
    kids_sold <- floor(kids_survive * 0.5)
    revenue <- kids_sold * 6000  # Average KSh 6,000 per goat
    
    # Costs
    feed_cost <- total_goats * 800 * 12
    vet_cost <- total_goats * 500
    labor_cost <- if_else(total_goats > 20, 30000, 0)  # Hire help at 20+ goats
    infrastructure <- if_else(yr == 1, 150000, 0)  # Predator-proof housing Year 1
    
    costs <- feed_cost + vet_cost + labor_cost + infrastructure
  }
  
  tibble(
    year = yr,
    herd_size = total_goats,
    revenue_ksh = revenue,
    costs_ksh = costs,
    profit_ksh = revenue - costs,
    cumulative_profit = cumsum(profit_ksh)[yr + 1]
  )
})

# Create animated growth chart
fig2 <- plot_ly(herd_projection, x = ~year, y = ~herd_size,
                type = 'scatter', mode = 'lines+markers',
                line = list(color = '#2E7D32', width = 3),
                marker = list(size = 12, color = '#2E7D32'),
                text = ~paste("Year", year, "<br>Herd Size:", herd_size, "goats"),
                hoverinfo = 'text') %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Herd Growth Projection (Starting with 7 Goats)</b>",
                      x = 0),
         xaxis = list(title = "Year"),
         yaxis = list(title = "Number of Goats"),
         plot_bgcolor = '#F5F5F5')

fig2








Revenue & Profitability Timeline


Code
# Create financial projection chart
fig3 <- plot_ly(herd_projection, x = ~year) %>%
  add_bars(y = ~revenue_ksh, name = "Revenue",
           marker = list(color = "#4CAF50")) %>%
  add_bars(y = ~costs_ksh, name = "Costs",
           marker = list(color = "#F44336")) %>%
  add_lines(y = ~profit_ksh, name = "Net Profit",
            line = list(color = 'black', width = 3, dash = 'dash'),
            marker = list(size = 10, color = 'black')) %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Financial Projections (5-Year Timeline)</b>",
                      x = 0),
         xaxis = list(title = "Year"),
         yaxis = list(title = "Amount (KSh)"),
         barmode = 'group',
         plot_bgcolor = '#F5F5F5',
         hovermode = 'x unified')

fig3












‚ö†Ô∏è Break-Even Analysis



Initial Investment: KSh 150,000 (predator-proof housing) + ongoing costs
Break-Even Point: Year 3
Year 1: Large infrastructure investment ‚Üí Negative (Predator-proof housing critical) Year 2: Revenue begins, still recovering investment Year 3: Positive cash flow begins Year 4-5: Accelerating profits as herd multiplies
Critical Success Factor: Predator-proof housing prevents losses like the 4 sheep lost to hyenas

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
text:
üèóÔ∏è Analysis 3: Predator-Proof Infrastructure

The Hyena Problem


Code
# Infrastructure options for predator protection
infrastructure_options <- tibble(
  option = c("Basic Wooden Fence", "Chain-Link + Wire", 
             "Stone Wall + Roof", "Full Security (Stone + Lights + Dogs)"),
  initial_cost = c(50000, 100000, 150000, 250000),
  maintenance_annual = c(10000, 5000, 3000, 8000),
  protection_level = c(40, 70, 90, 95),  # % effective
  lifespan_years = c(3, 7, 15, 15),
  expected_loss_pct = c(20, 10, 3, 1)  # % of herd lost annually
) %>%
  mutate(
    cost_per_year = initial_cost / lifespan_years + maintenance_annual,
    loss_value_year = (7 * expected_loss_pct / 100) * 6000,  # Value of lost goats
    total_annual_cost = cost_per_year + loss_value_year
  )

fig4 <- plot_ly(infrastructure_options,
                x = ~option, y = ~total_annual_cost,
                type = 'bar',
                marker = list(color = ~protection_level,
                             colorscale = 'RdYlGn',
                             showscale = TRUE,
                             colorbar = list(title = "Protection<br>Level (%)")),
                text = ~paste("KSh", comma(round(total_annual_cost, 0))),
                textposition = 'outside',
                hovertemplate = paste('<b>%{x}</b><br>',
                                     'Total Annual Cost: KSh %{y:,.0f}<br>',
                                     'Protection Level: %{marker.color}%<br>',
                                     '<extra></extra>')) %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Predator Protection Options - Total Annual Cost</b><br><sub>Includes infrastructure + expected losses</sub>",
                      x = 0),
         xaxis = list(title = ""),
         yaxis = list(title = "Total Annual Cost (KSh)"),
         plot_bgcolor = '#F5F5F5')

fig4












üõ°Ô∏è Recommendation: Stone Wall + Roof



Why: - 95% reduction in losses (vs 20% loss with basic fence) - Long lifespan (15 years) - Lowest total annual cost when factoring in prevented losses - Peace of mind after losing 4 sheep to hyenas
Investment: KSh 150,000 upfront Savings: Prevents ~KSh 8,400/year in losses (vs basic fence) Payback: 2-3 years through prevented losses + increased productivity
Additional Measures: - Guard dogs (traditional livestock guardian breeds) - Community cooperative night watching - Clear vegetation around housing (visibility)

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
text:
üìÖ Analysis 4: Seasonal Management Calendar


Code
# Create seasonal management heatmap
months <- month.name
activities <- c("Breeding", "Kidding", "Feeding Costs", "Disease Risk",
                "Market Prices", "Fodd

er Availability")

# Generate seasonal patterns
seasonal_data <- expand.grid(
  month = factor(months, levels = months),
  activity = activities
) %>%
  mutate(
    intensity = case_when(
      activity == "Breeding" & month %in% c("October", "November", "March") ~ 9,
      activity == "Breeding" ~ 5,
      
      activity == "Kidding" & month %in% c("March", "April", "August", "September") ~ 10,
      activity == "Kidding" ~ 2,
      
      activity == "Feeding Costs" & month %in% c("January", "February", "July", "August") ~ 10,
      activity == "Feeding Costs" ~ 5,
      
      activity == "Disease Risk" & month %in% c("April", "May", "November") ~ 8,
      activity == "Disease Risk" ~ 4,
      
      activity == "Market Prices" & month %in% c("December", "April") ~ 10,
      activity == "Market Prices" ~ 6,
      
      activity == "Fodder Availability" & month %in% c("April", "May", "October", "November") ~ 10,
      activity == "Fodder Availability" & month %in% c("January", "February") ~ 3,
      TRUE ~ 5
    )
  )

# Create heatmap
fig5 <- plot_ly(data = seasonal_data,
                x = ~month, y = ~activity, z = ~intensity,
                type = "heatmap",
                colorscale = "RdYlGn",
                reversescale = FALSE,
                hovertemplate = paste('%{y}<br>',
                                     '%{x}<br>',
                                     'Intensity: %{z}/10<br>',
                                     '<extra></extra>'),
                colorbar = list(title = "Intensity")) %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Seasonal Management Calendar - Homabay County</b>",
                      x = 0),
         xaxis = list(title = ""),
         yaxis = list(title = ""),
         plot_bgcolor = 'white')

fig5












üìÜ Key Seasonal Actions



March-May (Long Rains): - Peak fodder availability - stockpile/make hay - Plan breeding for August-September kidding - High disease risk - deworm, vaccinate - Monitor for pneumonia (wet, cold)
June-August (Dry Season): - Kidding season - extra attention needed - Supplement feeding critical - Water management crucial - Predator vigilance (hungry season)
September-November (Short Rains): - Second breeding window - Fodder recovery - Market prices favorable (festive season approaching)
December-February (Dry): - Peak market prices (Christmas, New Year) - Best selling period - Feeding costs highest - Water stress management

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
section: üåç Analysis 5: Rachuonyo North vs Suba Comparison
text:
üåç Analysis 5: Rachuonyo North vs Suba Comparison


Code
# Compare two farm locations
location_data <- tibble(
  factor = c("Rainfall", "Pasture Quality", "Market Access", "Vet Services",
             "Labor Availability", "Land Cost", "Predator Risk", "Water Access"),
  rachuonyo_north = c(7, 6, 7, 6, 8, 5, 8, 6),  # Scores 1-10
  suba = c(8, 7, 6, 5, 7, 6, 6, 8)
) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(rachuonyo_north, suba),
               names_to = "location", values_to = "score") %>%
  mutate(location = if_else(location == "rachuonyo_north", 
                           "Rachuonyo North (Homa Hills)", "Suba"))

fig6 <- plot_ly(location_data, x = ~factor, y = ~score, color = ~location,
                colors = c("Rachuonyo North (Homa Hills)" = "#2E7D32",
                          "Suba" = "#1565C0"),
                type = 'bar',
                text = ~score,
                textposition = 'outside',
                hovertemplate = paste('<b>%{x}</b><br>',
                                     '%{fullData.name}<br>',
                                     'Score: %{y}/10<br>',
                                     '<extra></extra>')) %>%
  layout(title = list(text = "<b>Location Comparison: Rachuonyo North vs Suba</b>",
                      x = 0),
         xaxis = list(title = "", tickangle = -45),
         yaxis = list(title = "Score (1-10)", range = c(0, 10)),
         barmode = 'group',
         plot_bgcolor = '#F5F5F5')

fig6












üìç Location Strategy



Rachuonyo North (Homa Hills) - Primary Farm: - ‚úÖ Home area advantage (family, community) - ‚úÖ Better market access - ‚úÖ Higher labor availability - ‚ö†Ô∏è Higher predator risk (hyenas confirmed) - ‚ö†Ô∏è Need significant predator-proofing
Suba - Secondary Farm: - ‚úÖ Better rainfall and pasture - ‚úÖ Better water access (Lake proximity) - ‚úÖ Lower predator risk - ‚ö†Ô∏è More remote (market access) - ‚ö†Ô∏è Higher land costs
Recommended Strategy: 1. Start in Rachuonyo North (already done ‚úì) 2. Prove model with current 7 goats 3. Scale Rachuonyo to 50-100 goats by 2026 4. Expand to Suba as secondary location (2027+) 5. Geographic diversification reduces climate risk

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
text:
üî¨ Analysis 6: Disease Management & Veterinary Costs


Code
# Disease management schedule and costs
disease_schedule <- tibble(
  intervention = c("Deworming (Quarterly)", "PPR Vaccination", "CCPP Vaccination",
                   "Hoof Trimming", "Mineral Supplementation", "Emergency Vet Visits"),
  frequency_per_year = c(4, 1, 1, 2, 12, 2),
  cost_per_goat = c(50, 150, 100, 30, 40, 200),
  critical = c("Yes", "Critical", "Critical", "No", "Yes", "Variable")
) %>%
  mutate(
    annual_cost_per_goat = frequency_per_year * cost_per_goat,
    cost_for_7_goats = annual_cost_per_goat * 7,
    cost_for_50_goats = annual_cost_per_goat * 50
  )

datatable(disease_schedule %>%
            select(Intervention = intervention,
                   `Frequency/Year` = frequency_per_year,
                   `Cost per Goat (KSh)` = cost_per_goat,
                   `Annual Cost (7 goats)` = cost_for_7_goats,
                   `Annual Cost (50 goats)` = cost_for_50_goats,
                   Critical = critical),
          options = list(pageLength = 10, scrollX = TRUE),
          caption = "Table 2: Veterinary Care Schedule and Costs") %>%
  formatCurrency(c('Cost per Goat (KSh)', 'Annual Cost (7 goats)', 'Annual Cost (50 goats)'),
                 'KSh ')

title: Goat Farming Investment Analysis
text:
üí° Key Findings & Recommendations






üìä Summary Insights



1. Breed Selection: - Small East African goats are best for Homa Hills climate - Mix 70% SEA with 30% Galla for balance - Avoid pure exotic breeds (Boer, Toggenburg)
2. Financial Viability: - Break-even in Year 3 from current 7 goats - Requires KSh 150,000 infrastructure investment (Year 1) - Cumulative profit of KSh 500,000+ by Year 5
3. Predator Management: - Stone wall + roof = best long-term investment - Prevents losses worth KSh 8,000+/year - Essential after losing 4 sheep to hyenas
4. Seasonal Strategy: - Breed in March/October (align with rain patterns) - Sell in December (peak prices) - Stockpile fodder during wet seasons - Intensive care during dry months
5. Location Strategy: - Start and scale in Rachuonyo North (home advantage) - Expand to Suba later for diversification - Two locations reduce climate/disease risk
6. Scaling Path: - Current: 7 goats + 15 sheep - Year 1: Focus on predator-proofing + herd stabilization - Year 2-3: Grow to 25-30 goats - Year 4-5: Scale to 50-100 goats (commercial threshold) - 2027+: Consider Suba expansion

text:
Data Integration Projects

5. Health Information Exchange (HIE) Implementation


üîÑ Connecting Disparate Health Systems
Duration: 2022-2024 | Status: Pilot Phase | Facilities: 15


Challenge: - 15 health facilities using 4 different EMR systems - No patient data sharing between facilities - Duplicate tests and treatments - Fragmented patient histories
Solution: - Implemented Health Information Exchange (HIE) based on FHIR standards - Master Patient Index (MPI) for unique patient identification - Standardized data exchange protocols - Consent management system

title: Data Management Projects
text:
Data Quality Frameworks

6. Automated Data Quality Monitoring System


‚úÖ Proactive Data Quality Management
Developed: 2020 | Status: Used in 10+ projects


Problem: - Manual data quality checks time-consuming and error-prone - Quality issues discovered late in project lifecycle - Inconsistent quality standards across projects
Solution: - Developed comprehensive automated DQ monitoring framework - Implemented in R as reusable package - Integrated with REDCap, CSV imports, and SQL databases
Framework Components:
1. Data Quality Dimensions: - Completeness: Missing data detection - Validity: Range and format checks - Consistency: Cross-field validation - Timeliness: Data entry delays - Accuracy: Logical inconsistencies - Uniqueness: Duplicate detection
2. Automated Checks:
# Example DQ checks
dq_framework <- DataQualityChecker$new(data)

# Completeness checks
dq_framework$check_completeness(
  required_vars = c("patient_id", "visit_date", "outcome"),
  threshold = 0.95  # 95% completeness required
)

# Validity checks
dq_framework$check_ranges(
  age = c(18, 100),
  bp_systolic = c(80, 220),
  bp_diastolic = c(40, 130)
)

# Consistency checks
dq_framework$check_consistency(
  rules = list(
    "death_date >= enrollment_date",
    "if outcome == 'pregnant' then sex == 'Female'",
    "if hiv_positive then hiv_test_date exists"
  )
)

# Generate report
dq_framework$generate_report(output = "html")
3. Reporting: - Automated daily/weekly reports - Traffic light system (red/yellow/green) - Drill-down capabilities to problem records - Trend analysis over time
Impact Across Projects: - ‚úÖ DQ issues detected 70% earlier in project lifecycle - ‚úÖ Data cleaning time reduced by 50% - ‚úÖ Standardized quality metrics across organization - ‚úÖ Used in 10+ studies managing 200,000+ records
Technologies: R (tidyverse, assertr, validate), R Markdown, Git
Social Media Highlight: > ‚ÄúPrevention > Correction in data management! Our automated DQ framework detects issues 70% earlier and cuts cleaning time in half. Now deployed across 10+ studies. Open-source release coming soon! #DataQuality #OpenScience #RStats‚Äù
GitHub Repository ‚Üí | Documentation ‚Üí

When live APIs aren‚Äôt available during render, this page uses small simulated datasets so the visuals still display.

title: Politics & Governance Analytics
text:
üåç Governance Indicators (WGI)


Code
if (wdi_ok) {
  library(WDI)
  countries <- c("KEN","UGA","TZA","RWA","ETH")
  wgi_codes <- c(rule_of_law = "RL.EST", gov_eff = "GE.EST", voice = "VA.EST")
  wgi <- map_dfr(names(wgi_codes), function(nm){
    code <- wgi_codes[[nm]]
    WDI(country = countries, indicator = code, start = 2005, end = 2023) %>%
      as_tibble() %>% mutate(ind = nm)
  }) %>% rename(value = 3)
} else {
  set.seed(1)
  wgi <- expand.grid(country = c("KEN","UGA","TZA","RWA","ETH"), year = 2005:2023, ind = c("rule_of_law","gov_eff","voice")) %>%
    as_tibble() %>% mutate(value = rnorm(n(), 0, 0.6))
}

p <- wgi %>%
  filter(ind == "gov_eff") %>%
  mutate(country = factor(country, levels = c("KEN","UGA","TZA","RWA","ETH"))) %>%
  plot_ly(x = ~year, y = ~value, color = ~country, type = 'scatter', mode = 'lines') %>%
  layout(title = 'Government Effectiveness (WGI): Kenya vs Region', yaxis = list(title = 'Estimate (Std)'), xaxis = list(title = 'Year'))

p

title: Politics & Governance Analytics
Politics & Governance Analytics
text:
üß≠ V-Dem Democracy Index


Code
# If you place a CSV at projects/politics-governance/data/vdem_kenya_region.csv
# with columns: country, year, vdem_index (0-1), we'll load it. Otherwise simulate.
local_path <- 'projects/politics-governance/data/vdem_kenya_region.csv'
if (file.exists(local_path)) {
  vdem <- readr::read_csv(local_path, show_col_types = FALSE)
} else {
  set.seed(4)
  vdem <- expand.grid(country = c('KEN','UGA','TZA','RWA','ETH'), year = 1995:2023) %>%
    as_tibble() %>% mutate(vdem_index = pmax(0, pmin(1, 0.55 + 0.02*(country=='KEN') + 0.003*(year-2005) + rnorm(n(),0,0.06))))
}

plot_ly(vdem %>% filter(country %in% c('KEN','UGA','TZA','RWA','ETH')),
        x = ~year, y = ~vdem_index, color = ~country,
        type = 'scatter', mode = 'lines') %>%
  layout(title = 'V-Dem Democracy Index: Kenya vs Region',
         yaxis = list(title = 'Index (0-1)', rangemode = 'tozero'),
         xaxis = list(title = 'Year'))

2. KEMRI Cancer Dashboard Project

Overview
Position: Data Manager & Analyst
Project: Oncology data transformation ‚Üí Cancer epidemiology dashboards
Impact: Policy-driving insights for Kenya cancer care
Publications: 3 papers (cancer epidemiology)


Key Insights from Dashboard

1. Lost to Follow-Up Crisis

>60% of cancer patients lost to follow-up
Major barrier to treatment completion
System failure in continuity of care
Implications for survival outcomes



2. Financial Barriers

High out-of-pocket expenditure
Catastrophic health costs forcing treatment abandonment
Financial constraints on patients AND families
Economic burden extends beyond patient
Insurance gap analysis needed



3. Mental Health Dimension

Significant mental health issues among cancer patients
Psychological distress in patients and caregivers
Depression, anxiety, hopelessness
Lack of psycho-oncology services
Mental health support gaps in cancer care pathway



4. Young Population Affected

Unexpected proportion of young people with cancer
Different from typical age distribution in high-income countries
Implications for years of life lost
Economic impact on productive population
Need for age-specific interventions



5. High Esophageal Cancer Burden

Very high esophageal cancer rates
Particular problem in certain regions (Nyanza)
Dietary and environmental risk factors
Late-stage diagnosis common
Poor prognosis
Geographic clustering patterns



6. HIV-Related Cancers

Significant burden of HIV-associated cancers
Kaposi‚Äôs sarcoma
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
Cervical cancer (HPV/HIV interaction)
Double burden: HIV + cancer
Treatment complexity



7. Pediatric Cancer Burden

Children‚Äôs cancers significant
Leukemias, lymphomas, Wilms tumor
Family devastation
Treatment abandonment due to costs
Specialized care needs
Long-term survivor care challenges




Additional Scientific Insights to Include

Late-Stage Diagnosis

Majority present at advanced stages (III/IV)
Limited screening programs
Healthcare access barriers
Symptom awareness gaps

Geographic Disparities

Urban vs rural access differences
Regional variation in cancer types
Distance to treatment centers
County-level inequalities

Treatment Abandonment

Financial toxicity leading to non-completion
Transport costs

5. Advanced Analytics Projects

Project 1: Sentiment Analysis - Kenya Twitter Health Discourse ‚≠ê
Data Source: Twitter API / Kaggle Kenya tweets dataset
Analyses: - Topic modeling: What health issues trend? - Sentiment analysis: Public opinion on NHIF, SHA - Network analysis: Influential voices in health policy - Temporal patterns: During COVID vs now - Geographic patterns: Urban vs rural sentiment
Methods: - NLP with tidytext - BERT for sentiment classification - LDA for topic modeling - Network graphs with igraph
Visualizations: - Word clouds (positive/negative) - Sentiment time series - Topic evolution over time - Network graph of health discourse - Interactive topic explorer



Project 2: Machine Learning - Health Insurance Enrollment Prediction ‚≠ê
Data Source: Kaggle health insurance dataset + simulated Kenya data
Problem: Predict which informal sector workers will enroll in NHIF
Methods: - Logistic regression (baseline) - Random forest - XGBoost - Neural network - Model comparison and selection
Features: - Demographics - Employment type - Income level - Distance to health facility - Previous health shocks - Behavioral nudges received
Visualizations: - ROC curves comparing models - Feature importance plots - Confusion matrices - SHAP values for interpretability - Interactive prediction calculator
Output: Policy recommendations for improving enrollment



Project 3: Predictive Analytics - Maternal Health Risk Scoring ‚≠ê
Data Source: Kaggle maternal health dataset
Problem: Early warning system for maternal complications
Methods: - Risk score development - Time-to-event analysis - Classification models - Threshold optimization
Features: - Age, parity, BMI - Blood pressure, blood sugar - Antenatal care visits - Distance to facility - Socioeconomic factors
Visualizations: - Risk score distribution - Calibration curves - Decision curve analysis - Interactive risk calculator
Application: Mobile health (mHealth) integration for community health workers



Project 4: Time Series Forecasting - Disease Outbreak Prediction
Data Source: Kenya Ministry of Health disease surveillance data / WHO data
Focus: Malaria, cholera, dengue patterns
Methods: - ARIMA models - Prophet (Facebook) - LSTM neural networks - Seasonal decomposition
Visualizations: - Forecast with confidence intervals - Seasonal patterns - Outbreak probability map - Early warning dashboard

6. Survival Analysis Project (Oncology)

Project: Cancer Survival Analysis - KEMRI Experience ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Context: Showcase your KEMRI work on ‚Äúvery big and impactful project‚Äù
Data Source: - SEER cancer registry (public) - Kaggle oncology datasets - Simulated data based on Kenya cancer patterns
Analyses: 1. Survival Curves: Kaplan-Meier by cancer type 2. Cox Proportional Hazards: Risk factors 3. Competing Risks: Accounting for other causes of death 4. Recurrence Analysis: Time to progression 5. Treatment Effectiveness: Comparing protocols 6. Prognostic Models: Nomograms
Specific Focus Areas: - Cervical cancer (high burden in Kenya) - Esophageal cancer (common in Nyanza region) - Breast cancer survival disparities - Effect of late diagnosis on outcomes - Urban vs rural survival differences
Methods: - Kaplan-Meier curves - Log-rank tests - Cox regression - Random survival forests - Competing risks regression - Conditional survival probabilities
Visualizations: - Interactive survival curves (plotly) - Forest plots of hazard ratios - Nomogram for risk prediction - Time-dependent ROC curves - Restricted mean survival time plots - Dynamic survival probability calculator
Sections: 1. Background: Cancer burden in Kenya 2. KEMRI context: Brief mention of your work 3. Data and Methods 4. Results: - Survival by stage at diagnosis - Risk factors for poor outcomes - Treatment effectiveness - Prognostic model 5. Policy Implications: - Early detection importance - Geographic disparities - Resource allocation
Key Message: Strong survival analysis skills + health research experience + Kenya context
